articles.headline: Trump Widens Lead After Biden’s Debate Debacle, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: Donald Trump is ahead of President Biden by six percentage points among likely voters in a new national survey. Overall, 74 percent of voters view Mr. Biden as too old for the job, an uptick since the debate.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump is ahead of President Biden by six percentage points among likely voters in a new national survey. Overall, 74 percent of voters view Mr. Biden as too old for the job, an uptick since the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s lead in the 2024 presidential race has widened after President Biden’s fumbling debate performance last week, as concerns that Mr. Biden is too old to govern effectively rose to new heights among Democrats and independent voters, a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College showed.

articles.headline: Should Biden Quit? Democrats Weigh Potential Rewards and Steep Risks
articles.snippet: Picking a new nominee could give Democrats a jolt of energy. But it could bring division and a crash-course campaign with no room for error.
articles.abstract: Picking a new nominee could give Democrats a jolt of energy. But it could bring division and a crash-course campaign with no room for error.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Is Xenophobia on Chinese Social Media Teaching Real-World Hate?
articles.snippet: Violent attacks on foreigners have prompted a debate about extreme nationalism online in a country that heavily censors information the government bans.
articles.abstract: Violent attacks on foreigners have prompted a debate about extreme nationalism online in a country that heavily censors information the government bans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video posted last year on Chinese social media showed more than 100 Japanese children, supposedly at an elementary school in Shanghai, gathered in their schoolyard. Chinese subtitles quoted two students leading the group as screaming: “Shanghai is ours. Soon the whole China will be ours, too.”

articles.headline: Iranians’ Demand for Their Leaders: Fix the Economy
articles.snippet: In a series of interviews, virtually every resident of Tehran listed Iran’s sickly economy as the No. 1 issue for the country’s next president.
articles.abstract: In a series of interviews, virtually every resident of Tehran listed Iran’s sickly economy as the No. 1 issue for the country’s next president.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the working-class neighborhood of Tehran surrounding Imam Hussein Square, the side streets and alleys are lined with secondhand stores and small repair shops for refurbishing all manner of household goods. But with little to do, most shopkeepers idle in front of their stores.

articles.headline: Things to Take to College That You Can’t Buy at Target
articles.snippet: They won’t add bulk to the car or much cost to the bill, but they’ll help keep your college student safer. Pepperoni is also involved.
articles.abstract: They won’t add bulk to the car or much cost to the bill, but they’ll help keep your college student safer. Pepperoni is also involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Extra-long sheets. Shower shoes. The wall hooks and putty that hold things up but don’t leave marks.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Why a New Conservative Brain Trust Is Resettling Across America
articles.snippet: Pro-Trump professionals aren’t just talking about remaking Western civilization. Some are uprooting their lives to show that they mean it.
articles.abstract: Pro-Trump professionals aren’t just talking about remaking Western civilization. Some are uprooting their lives to show that they mean it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Claremont Institute has been located in Southern California since its founding in the late 1970s. From its perch in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, it has become a leading intellectual center of the pro-Trump right.

articles.headline: A Hacker Stole OpenAI Secrets, Raising Fears That China Could, Too
articles.snippet: A security breach at the maker of ChatGPT last year revealed internal discussions among researchers and other employees, but not the code behind OpenAI’s systems.
articles.abstract: A security breach at the maker of ChatGPT last year revealed internal discussions among researchers and other employees, but not the code behind OpenAI’s systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, a hacker gained access to the internal messaging systems of OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, and stole details about the design of the company’s A.I. technologies.

articles.headline: Apartments Could Be the Next Real Estate Business to Struggle
articles.snippet: Owners of some rental buildings are starting to struggle because of rising interest rates and waning demand in some once booming Sun Belt cities.
articles.abstract: Owners of some rental buildings are starting to struggle because of rising interest rates and waning demand in some once booming Sun Belt cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might seem like a great time to own apartment buildings.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Legal Conservatives’ Long Game: Amp Up Presidential Power but Kneecap Federal Agencies
articles.snippet: Blockbuster decisions by the Supreme Court’s Republican-appointed supermajority — expanding one kind of executive branch authority while undercutting another — were no contradiction.
articles.abstract: Blockbuster decisions by the Supreme Court’s Republican-appointed supermajority — expanding one kind of executive branch authority while undercutting another — were no contradiction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seemed to take two views of executive power this term, saying presidents should have immunity to free them from constraints while also scaling back the ability of the executive branch to impose regulations.

articles.headline: Fight Over Seabed Agency Leadership Turns Nasty
articles.snippet: An election over the future of a United Nations-affiliated organization could determine whether the Pacific Ocean floor will soon be mined for metals used in electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: An election over the future of a United Nations-affiliated organization could determine whether the Pacific Ocean floor will soon be mined for metals used in electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allegations of possible payments to help secure votes. Claims of abuse of agency funds by top diplomats. A possible job offer to entice a candidate to withdraw from a race.

articles.headline: Europe Tells China’s Carmakers: Get Ready to Pay Tariffs
articles.snippet: The European Union took the next step toward collecting heavy tariffs on electric vehicles, ahead of a final decision in October.
articles.abstract: The European Union took the next step toward collecting heavy tariffs on electric vehicles, ahead of a final decision in October.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union took the next step on Thursday toward collecting new tariffs on Chinese electric cars, telling automakers to obtain guarantees from banks that they would be able to pay the taxes set to be made final in October.

articles.headline: Netflix Show Earns Its Saudi Creator Plaudits, and a Prison Sentence
articles.snippet: In a video plea for help, Abdulaziz Almuzaini — a dual Saudi-American citizen — described how the authorities had accused him of promoting extremism through a cartoon franchise.
articles.abstract: In a video plea for help, Abdulaziz Almuzaini — a dual Saudi-American citizen — described how the authorities had accused him of promoting extremism through a cartoon franchise.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the outside, the past few years looked like the peak of Abdulaziz Almuzaini’s career.

articles.headline: U.S. and Israel Voice New Optimism About Cease-Fire as Gaza Talks Resume
articles.snippet: A senior White House official called progress in talks with Hamas “a breakthrough,” while Israel was more restrained, and both said major obstacles to a truce remained.
articles.abstract: A senior White House official called progress in talks with Hamas “a breakthrough,” while Israel was more restrained, and both said major obstacles to a truce remained.
articles.lead_paragraph: American and Israeli officials on Thursday expressed renewed optimism over a cease-fire deal in the Gaza Strip, after Hamas revised its position and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel then told President Biden that he was sending a new delegation of negotiators to the stalled talks.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Michael D. Shear and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Why More French Youth Are Voting for the Far Right
articles.snippet: Most young people in France usually don’t vote or they back the left. That is still true, but support has surged for the far right, whose openly racist past can feel to them like ancient history.
articles.abstract: Most young people in France usually don’t vote or they back the left. That is still true, but support has surged for the far right, whose openly racist past can feel to them like ancient history.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, a French punk rock band coined a rallying cry against the country’s far right that retained its punch over decades. The chant, still shouted at protests by the left, is “La jeunesse emmerde le Front National,” which cannot be translated well without curse words, but essentially tells the far right to get lost.
articles.byline: By Aurelien Breeden, Aida Alami and Dmitry Kostyukov

articles.headline: Some Countries Are Trying a Four-Day Workweek. Greece Wants a Six-Day One.
articles.snippet: The country, which already has the European Union’s longest average workweek, wants to add another day in some cases, bucking a growing business trend.
articles.abstract: The country, which already has the European Union’s longest average workweek, wants to add another day in some cases, bucking a growing business trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the rest of the world zigs toward a four-day workweek, Greece is opting to zag.
articles.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Amelia Nierenberg
